nexttext: and the recovery rate $\beta$, depends linearly on the domain size,

nexttext: where $I_0$ is the initial peak intensity and $\sigma$ is the RL cross section. To model the population dynamics of the molecules we use Embaye \textit{et al.}'s two-species non-interacting molecule model, in which undamaged molecules reversibly transition into a damaged state during degradation \cite{embaye08.01}.  In this model the undamaged population's fractional number density during decay ($t\leq t_D$) is
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="I_{RL}(t)=I_{0}e^{\sigma n(t)}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>I</mi><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>L</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: where $I_0$ is the initial peak intensity and $\sigma$ is the RL cross section. To model the population dynamics of the molecules we use Embaye \textit{et al.}'s two-species non-interacting molecule model, in which undamaged molecules reversibly transition into a damaged state during degradation \cite{embaye08.01}.  In this model the undamaged population's fractional number density during decay ($t\leq t_D$) is
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="n(t)=\frac{\beta}{\beta+\alpha I}+\frac{\alpha I}{\beta+\alpha I}e^{-(\beta+%
\alpha I)t}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>β</mi><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>I</mi></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>I</mi></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>I</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $t_D$ is the time at which the pump is turned off, $\alpha$ is the decay parameter, $I$ is the pump intensity, and $\beta$ is the recovery rate.  Using Equations \ref{eqn:int}--\ref{eqn:rec} we can model the RL peak intensity's decay and recovery as a function of time and extract the relevant dynamical parameters, with  $\alpha=3.16(\pm 0.10) \times 10^{-2}$ cm$^2$W$^{-1}$min$^{-1}$ and $\beta =3.75( \pm 0.18) \times 10^{-2}$ min$^{-1}$.  The decay parameter, $\alpha$, is found to be smaller than the previously measured values for DO11/PMMA \cite{howel02.01,howel04.01,embaye08.01,Ramini12.01,Ramini13.01}, which means that the addition of nanoparticles improves the materials photostability. Additionally, we find that the recovery rate of DO11+ZrO$_2$/PMMA is larger than any previous measurement \cite{howel02.01,howel04.01,embaye08.01,Anderson11.01,Anderson13.01,Anderson14.01,Anderson14.02,Ramini12.01,Ramini13.01,Anderson15.04}, implying that the addition of ZrO$_2$ NPs helps aid the recovery process.  An explanation for these effects is that the introduction of NPs can change the free energy advantage $\lambda$, and density parameter, $\rho$, such that the average domain size is greater with NPs than without \cite{Ramini12.01, Ramini13.01,Anderson14.02}.    

While a precise determination of the domain parameters is beyond the scope of the current study, we can estimate the modified domain parameters by considering the effect of the average domain size on the recovery rates.  Previously it was shown that the average domain size is given by \cite{Anderson14.02}:
